questions.text: A drummer presents with hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals loss of contraction of the tensor tympani and the stapedius, which prevents damage to the eardrum and middle ear ossicles. These muscles are most likely controlled by which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tensor tympani and the stapedius are supplied by Trigeminal and facial nerves respectively.

questions.text: A 60 year old man with a known history of lung cancer comes to you due to hoarseness & difficulty in swallowing. He has no disturbance in vision & hearing. On examination there is loss of gag reflex on left side, when the patient is prompted to say “ah”, the uvula deviates to right side. His left shoulder is drooped & strength is reduced during left shoulder shrug testing. Chest X-ray & MRI of head demonstrates multiple lesions consistent with metastasis. A lesion involving which of the anatomical structure is most likely responsible for this patients' symptoms –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Patient has involvement of 9, 10, 11 nerve so. F. Jugular can justify this.

questions.text: Through which of the marked foramen, Covid may spread to meninges ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A is Cribriform plate through which Covid passes

questions.text: Which nerve lesion could produce the condition where stimulation of right cornea results in blinking of the left eye but not the right eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right facial is gone because rest of the pathway is working. In unilateral absent involvement of facial n. and in bilateral  case involvement of trigeminal is seen

questions.text: Which of the following passes behind the Marked “A”structure ?

A is carotid sheath and sympathetic trunk lies behind it

The dorsal root is both sensory and motor.

questions.text: A 50 years old man comes to you with complaints of dry eye. For proper evaluation Schirmer’s test is performed. Anatomically this test evaluates the function of which of the following marked muscle:

questions.text: Tongue muscle which is NOT developed from occipital myotome:

questions.text: A 37 year old previously healthy man comes to the office for evaluation of enlarged lymph nodes. He has an 8 week history of progressively enlarging cervical lymph nodes associated with subjective fever, fatigue & drenching night sweat. After initial assessment the patient undergoes excisional biopsy of enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of neck. Two weeks later during a follow up visit, he describe difficulty in overhead activities such as combing his hair or placing dishes in the overhead shelves. Examination shows a left shoulder droop with weakness of left arm abduction above the horizontal position. Other shoulder movements are normal & there is no sensory loss. Which of the following muscle is most likely paralyzed in this patient –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spinal acc. Nerve is injured in this case which supplies trapezius

Great auricular nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with history of headache, vertigo, ataxia and intermittent pain and weakness in his left arm initiate by using the left arm for daily activities. On examination, the left radial pulse is weak and the systolic BP on the left side is reduced by 30 mm HG. Doppler Ultrasound reveals reversal of flow in the left vertebral artery. What is likely underlying pathology which would explain the patient’s condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is subclavian steal syndrome, and Critical stenosis of First part of Subclavian artery can only explain the pts condition

questions.text: Which of the following arteries involved in the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus is NOT a branch of the External Carotid artery.

Anterior Ethmoidal is a branch of ophthalmic A. which isa branch of INT.Carotid A.

questions.text: In dislocation of the jaw, displacement of the articular disc beyond the articular tubercle of the temporomandibular joint results from spasm or excessive contraction of the following muscle:

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall from his garage roof. These deficits are characteristically seen in which of the following syndromes ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

These deficits are characteristically seen in Brown-Séquard

questions.text: A patient is brought in the emergency room who has received a stab wound in the right side of the chest below and medial to the coracoid process of the scapula. A severed artery was found deep at this location. After initial stabilization, you start repairing with one of senior surgeon. You make an incision through the skin and subcutaneous tissue just below the clavicle, then cut the clavicular head of the pectoralis major muscle and retract it downward. Next you get a partially severed muscle running downward and medially from the coracoid process. You divide the remaining fibers of the muscle and retracts it downward. This exposes a bloody fat-filled space full of vessels and nerves.Which space or cavity was opened when the muscles were reflected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Description is of axillary artery deep to Pectoralis minor, overall it is about Axillary space

Latissimus dorsi is the only muscle which does adduction among given options.

Ulnar N. passes

Middle finger

Constriction of blood vessels on the hand

questions.text: A bullfighter suffers a laceration of the Musculo- cutaneous nerve during a bullfight. Which of the following conditions is most likely to have occurred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lack of sweating on the lateral side of the forearm because this nerve is responsible for cutaneous supply including sympathetic supply in lateral side of the forearm

questions.text: A 10 years old boy is brought to the emergency department because he is no longer able to fully extend the fingers of his right hand. he had suffered a right fibula fracture in a road accident 2 weeks before and was given a pair of crutches to use while his leg recovered. He lost that set of crutches and therefore he has been using his taller friend's crutches. which have been putting a lot of pressure on his axilla. On physical exam he is found to have a wrist drop and decreased sensation over his posterior forearm and dorsal hand. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the patients symptoms –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radial

Wrist drop – Radial Nerve

questions.text: A 10 years old boy falls and fractures his humerus. Fracture causes laceration of a nerve, which results in weakness in the ability to extend the hand at the wrist. There is also numbness in the skin over the anatomical snuffbox. Which of the following arteries that shares the course with the affected nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Profunda brachii accompanies  affected nerve (Radial)

choices.text: Distal insertion of the extensor tendon.

questions.text: A football player presents to your clinic with a swollen index finger. When told to make a fist the young man can bend his index finger at the PIP but not at the DIP joint. Which tendon likely ruptured in the injury?
questions.solution:

Flexor Digitorum Profundus

questions.text: Which structure lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Femoral A. lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that began about 6 hours ago. She also complains of vague pelvic pain over the last few months, but says her pain has never been this severe. Her temperature is 38.6° C, blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 17/min. Physical examination shows a moderately distended abdomen. There is a tender bulge below the inguinal ligament, just lateral to the pubic tubercle. The overlying skin is erythematous. Which of the following structures is most likely immediately lateral to the bulge?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Femoral vein 

Femoral vein lies  immediately lateral to the Femoral Canal

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman was involved in an automobile accident. Her car skidded into a tree & she was thrown forward, striking her right knee on the dashboard. At examination in the emergency department, she was found to have a posterior fracture dislocation of her right hip joint. What bone or bones got fractured?

questions.text: A 36 years old patient reports her condition characterized by tingling, numbness and burning pain in her outer thigh. The diagnosis of meralgia paresthetica is made by you. Which of the following nerve is involved in this condition:-

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman complains of weakness when she extends her thigh and rotates it laterally. Which of the following muscles is paralyzed?

Gluteus maximus

Superior Gluteal nerve supplies marked muscle (Gluteus medius)

questions.text: A knife wound penetrates the superficial vein that terminates in the popliteal vein. Bleeding occurs from which of the following vessels?

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of easy fatigability. Her menstrual cycles are regular and her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Which of the following muscles contributes most to the described movement?

Psoas major is chief flexor of Hip joint

questions.text: A 54 years old female has difficulty walking after an injury to her right foot. Physical examination of right ankle reveals there is swelling and tenderness. Lateral ligament is injured in Inversion injury

choices.text: Is a branch of the celiac trunk
Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen
Supplies the greater curvature of stomach

questions.text: All of the following statements about the Splenic artery are true except that it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Has branches that anastomose freely within the spleen)
Explanation: This statement is false because the arterial supply within the spleen is generally considered to be via end arteries or functional end arteries. This means that the branches of the splenic artery that enter the spleen have very limited or no significant anastomotic (connecting) pathways with each other. If one of these branches is occluded, the specific region of the spleen it supplies will likely undergo ischemia and infarction (tissue death due to lack of blood supply), as there are insufficient alternative blood supply routes.

Incorrect Options:

Option (A. Has a tortuous course)
Explanation: This statement is true. The splenic artery is well-known for its characteristic winding and twisting, or tortuous, path as it travels along the superior border of the pancreas toward the hilum of the spleen. This anatomical feature is often highlighted in textbooks and imaging.

Option (B. Is a branch of the celiac trunk)
Explanation: This statement is true. The celiac trunk is a major, unpaired artery branching from the abdominal aorta. It typically trifurcates (divides into three main branches) almost immediately after its origin. These three branches are the left gastric artery, the common hepatic artery, and the splenic artery.

Option (D. Supplies the greater curvature of stomach)
Explanation: This statement is true. The splenic artery gives rise to important branches that supply parts of the stomach, particularly along the greater curvature. These branches include the short gastric arteries (which supply the fundus and upper part of the greater curvature) and the left gastro-omental (gastroepiploic) artery (which runs along the greater curvature and supplies it, often anastomosing with the right gastro-omental artery).

choices.text: Arteriography of the abdominal aorta revealed blockage in the region of the bifurcation.
Only the right common iliac artery was involved by disease.
The gradual blockage of the aorta was caused by advanced arteriosclerosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man visited his physician complaining that he experiences severe pain in both legs when taking long walks. On questioning, about his sex life the patient admitted that he was experiencing difficulty with erection. The symptoms and signs displayed by this patient can be explained by the following statements except which?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Only the right common iliac artery was involved by disease.
